title: How many of the following 10 marginal seats in the House of Commons will change parties in the upcoming 2019 UK elections?
preds: Voting will be unpredictable. Marginal seats are more likely to change.

Based on the latest YouGov MRP report, it seems Richmond Park and Canterbury are the only polling certainties, with Richmond Park likely to go LibDem, and Canterbury, Labour. Cheltenham, Hastings and Rye, Crewe and Nantwitch, Bolsover and Brecon and Radnorshire lean Conservative. North East Fife and Kensington are tossups. Workington leans Labour. That means 3 seats seem to be flipping, with North East Fife and Kensington as tossups. I am inclined now to give North East Fife to the SNP and Kensington to Labour. So that's 3 or 4 changes.

It's likely that the Conservatives will retain most of their maginal seats. Hastings and Rye is most at risk as Amber Rudd is a high profile independent. The seats most likely to change would be the Labour held seats either going to the Conservatives or the Liberal Democrats.
Polling evidence, MRP research. Brexit position of Electorate weakening traditional party loyalties

Conservative Party marginal seats: Richmond Park will certainly go to the LibDems, Cheltenham too, though Cheltenham is on a knife edge and the Tories could retake it.  Labour Party marginal seats: Workington; Bolsover; Kensington; Crewe and Nantwitch are all likely to fall to the Tories.  Liberal Democrat Party marginal seats: Brecon and Radnorshire will go to the Tories.  The rest of the seats should remain unchanged.  I am not completely convinced the LibDems can bring home Cheltenham, but for now, my forecast is 7 changes.

There will be concerted effort and tactical voting in these seats - London is extremely anti Brexit and Cons will not hold on. SMP will hold. Lab & Lib may both shift half due to unpopular leaders and northern pro Brexi feeling
Based on what I have been reading in analytical aryicles
By making assumptions based on what I have heard on the BBC
some seats are more vulnerable than others not just because of the smaller majority but also the geography
Vote leave seats occupied by labour mps. Conservative politician in rye public comments. Lib Dem losing momentum and people want no that can influence policy
Tactical voting and Brexit considerations trumping traditional party loyalt

SNP should hold.  LibDem should hold. Given significant increase in youth enrolment and therefore turnout (the Greta effect?), Labour should hold or go to LibDem.  Given politics weariness in electorate, maybe less turnout of more traditional voters.

No or all shift is hardly likely. People who do not like Corbyn or Johnson would most likely vote Lib dem which might shift some of the marginal seats, as well as because of the silike of Corbyn, part of their seats might move to Tories
I think the most likely event with marginals is they switch...
I think the Conservatives will win a majority by winning marginal seats
To predict the outcome of the marginal seats
These seats will be subject to tactical voting.

Wales & Scotland are less likely to go Conservative with Brexit as the main driver of separation. Turnout is likely to be high. Remainers in London will probably switch from Conservatives to Lib-Dem, but over all shape is unlikely to change much. In any election random switching could move half of seats. Local polling is unreliable.
Think some but not many will change due to incumbency advantage
Richmond swing away from tories because of remainders; 3 labour seats lot to leave; Lib Dem’s life seat cos of withdrawing article 50
I think the a couple Tory seats will swing and a couple of Labour. Cant see SNP or Lib Dem losing. Labour might lose more than 2.
There have been a lot of changes since the last general election, and the issues are completely different, so it is likely many constituencies will see changes.
It was suggested that I should, new signup.

More people than ever are willing to behave tactically. Large numbers are disgusted by Tiry behaviour an£ will act to keep them out. BUT - the mindless who are taken in by Johnson’s pfaffing bluster will flock to him, driven he right wing press, somewhat countering this.
Because I think that this is critical to the overall result of the election

Lots of people will use their vote to push their Brexit agenda. Those who want to leave to EU may choose to swap their party allegiance in this election and vote Conservative in order to leave the EU.

Mostly based on current prediction markets projection: https://smarkets.com/event/829238/politics/uk/next-uk-general-election/overall-ge-majority but hard to tell the impact of targetted campaigning by groups like Momentum so tempering the confidence in the market.
Based on the information from news outlets and opinion polls to date.
A very high youth voter turnout will protect Labour in some of their marginals but hurt the Tories in many of theirs.

Because these seats are being targeted. Special efforts will be made to get the voters out to the polling booths.  I think 8 out of the 10 will change.
Forget leaflets: this election may be decided by shifting populations
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/dec/05/leaflets-election-campaigning
It is what the poll suggest.
Volatile electorate angry & distrustful of politicans motives.
Sorry but think it’s just a hunch for now.
It's extremely unlikely that key marginal seats will remain unchanged
Due to the political climate and the frustration of the electorate

Error in previous calculation corrected. Individually have below forecasts for change, outcome based on simulation model of all permutations of below probs: Hastings and Rye: 29%
Richmond Park: 75%
Cheltenham: 63%
North East Fife: 58%
Canterbury: 52%
Workington: 56%
Bolsover: 51%
Kensington: 75%
Crewe and Nantwich: 69%
Brecon and Radnorshire: 70%
Split with Brexit/party policies make it inevitable
Labour will lose more seats because their leader is not a convincing leader to turn voters to vote Labour.
I  think a couple of seats in Scotland will fall to the SNP and a couple of English seats will go back to the Tories
I expect 5 to swap, but more than 6 seems unlikely. No way there isn’t any that swap. I gave 3/4 a higher percentage to hedge against my over confidence.

Where things are so uncertain people are more likely to stick with a candidate they know, good or bad, and therefore incumbents will have more of an advantage.  So if this is the case less marginal seats are likely to switch, even though the overall chances of changing party are still quite high.

Don't have time to reassess with all the new polling data. 
131 seats are currently decided by fewer than 5000 votes.  31 decided by less than 2000.   Tightest electing in a lifetime - but then inflection points generally are.  Still challengers win inflection points about 1/4 of the time. ...

Whilst many are turned off politics at the moment, there are motivated minorities who will vote tactically. This may mean that whilst large swings are not seen nationally, seats held with small margins will be more likely to change.

Boris continues to do things right

Corbyn declining as an electoral force, Lib Dems contesting many marginal remain-voting seats. Brexit party announcing they will not run in marginal seats which the conservatives may win.

Rough estimate from informally reviewing the candidates: 
5 seats with 50% chance of turning over, 2 with 75% and 2 with 25%:
=> 0,6,37,45,12
Current median: 2,11,56,26,5
Correcting for this to 
0,6,45,40,9
I believe that 3 - 4 is most likely given the big pledges in the party manifestos

Atleast 4. Expecting 5
Canterbury, bolsover, crewe, brecon I also think workington. Expecting kensington to stay labour.
I’d expect all Labour seats to change hands and perhaps one other, putting the likely number at 5 or 6.

One more time, redoing the binomial numbers based on an average of 0.63, 10 trials, and then calculated for every value from 0 through 10, combining them into these question buckets.[1] I get the following: 1. None: .00004
2. 1 or 2: .0070 (.0008 + .0062)
3. 3 or 4: .1134 (.0285 + .0849)
4. 5 or 6: .4195 (.1734 + .2461)
5. 7 or more: .4599 (.2394 + .1529 + .0578 + .0098) I calculated the .63 average using estimates.[2] [1] https://www.stattrek.com/online-calculator/binomial.aspx
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/924694
For the source of per race probabilities and how I came up with these new numbers, see the link that follows: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/924694

Looking at each seat in turn: Hastings was narrowly retained by ex Con Minister Amber Rudd in 2017. 56% leave vote. I think this could go either way (Con, Lab). Richmond Park has recently switched back and forth between Con and LD. Large remain vote of 71% likely to mean LDs will win seat from Con this time.  Cheltenham held by Con but has strong LD presence and is 57% remain. LD likely to take this seat helped by Green Party standing down as part of remain alliance.  NE Fife is an ex LD stronghold won by SNP by 2 votes in 2017. Could revert back to LD but depends how strong Scottish independence vote is.  Brecon was won by LD from Con in a by election this year and could well be held by LD following the alliance with Plaid and the Greens.  52% leave vote. Likely to stay LD. Canterbury is a 55% remain constituency with a large student population.  Lab won from Con last time by a narrow margin. This time the election will be at the end of term. If students mobilise and vote in Canterbury rather than their home constituencies, Lab should hold. Workington voted 60% leave and has an older than average population.  This is a traditional Lab constituency and is being targeted by Con. Brexit party are also standing here and are likely to take votes from disgruntled voters who voted leave. This is likely to split the leave vote and may allow Lab to hang onto this seat. Bolsover has been a Lab constituency for decades and incumbent Dennis Skinner has also been there for decades.  Unlikely that he will be voted out although 70% voted leave. The Brexit party are standing here and this could result in the leave vote being split and Lab retaining the seat. Kensington is a difficult one to call. A highly affluent part of London, traditionally Con but with a 69% remain vote. Ex Con Minister Sam Gyimah standing for LDs this time around could result in the remain vote being split and Con taking the seat.  Crewe was narrowly won by Lab from Con last time and voted 60% leave. This one could go either way.  Tactical voting may well play a part in these constituencies and there are now numerous sites explaining who eg remain supporters in Kensington should vote for including sites by the vote remain alliance, the people' vote, etc.

[Erased calculations on this forecast because they were wrong and I don't wish to mislead anyone.]
See update: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/924879 Hastings & Rye: Sally-Ann Hart is a new Tory candidate running against Peter Chowney, the Labour candidate that came within 346 votes of beating the Tory incumbent Amber Rudd, who was the Home Secretary in the last election. It's been in Tory hands for an age and voted Leave by a ~10% margin. So, let's say 40% chance of a change.[1,2,3] Richmond Park: Zac Goldsmith is the Tory incumbent that won last time around by 45 votes over Sarah Olney of LIberal Democrats. Given the 71% vote for Remain, it's hard to see the Tories holding on to this seat, particularly when you consider that she one it from him in a by election in 2016. But, on the other hand, Zac Goldsmith is one of the wealthiest MPs. I'll give it 70% chance of a change.[4,5] Cheltenham: Alex Chalk of the Tories in the incumbent. There's a 15% plus margin to Remain and last election was a Liberal Democrat seat in 2010. Financial Times has an article that the odds favor Liberal Democrats here, so let's say 60% of a change.[6,7,8]  North East Fife: Liberal Democrat stronghold for years. Their Remain message is going to resonate with a +27% advantage to Remain votes. I think the chance of this flipping is almost a certainty, 90%.[9,10,11] Canterbury: Rosie Duffield is the Labour incumbent. She narrowly defeated the Tories in their stronghold last go around in a surprise win. The +9% remain vote will help, but everyone is going to be investing a lot of resources to win this seat. The key is that the Liberal Democrat Tim Walker pulled out of the race three days ago, which I think puts Rosie over the top. Only 20% chance of this seat flipping. [12,13] [Edit: Looks like Liberal Democrats are still fielding someone, which makes me think this has probably a 60% chance of flipping.] Workington: I think this says it all: "The Conservatives’ hopes of taking Workington will have been boosted this weekend by a Survation poll for the Daily Mail which found that they were on course to win by more than 4,000 votes, with a 10-point swing from Labour." I'd put it at about 95% chance this flips. [14,15] Bolsover: Dennis Skinner is Labour's "Beast of Bolsover", political royalty. Labour has been taking a beating here with 70% voting Leave. But, Skinner is the forever incumbent and well liked. I think he'll pull it out. Let's say 35% chance of flipping.[16,17] Kensington: Tempting to think that the Liberal Democrats will split the vote in this one and leave the door open for the Tories. But, Sam Gyimah, the Liberal Democrat candidate, was formerly a Tory and has recently made some remarks that will likely sink his bid, despite ~2/3 voting for Remain. Tories probably have about a 20% of taking this one, given they are fielding a newcomer.[18,19] Crewe and Nantwich: Laura Smith was a surprise win by Labour in 2017. She's a former school teacher and closely tied to Corbyn. Given a constituency that voted +20% on Leave, I think the chances are good, 80%, this flips to the Tories.[20,21] Brecon & Radnorshire: This seat was won by Liberal Democrat Jane Dodds in a by-election caused by a recall because the previous Tory MP has a scandal involving expense reports. It was seen as a test of Boris Johnson at the time. Conservatives have held this seat for the last two elections, and they have a fresh face in Fay Alicia Jones. I think there's a 80% this seat flips. Personally, I'd vote for Lady Lily the Pink of the Official Monster Raving Loony Party.[22,23] [1] http://democraticdashboard.com/constituency/hastings-and-rye/

[23] https://www.euronews.com/2019/08/01/why-is-the-brecon-by-election-so-important-to-boris-euronews-answers Yes, I know this answer is mental. But, I found it to be an interesting exercise. If someone can point me to a good explanation of determining probablistic outcomes across a set of probabilities for a binary outcome hitting a specified number of events, I'd like to see it. This strikes me as a straight-forward math problem at this point, but I don't think I have it right.

Living in two of these marginals I feel that both (NE Fife & RBKC) have an extremely high chance of change (for example NE Fife was won by the SNP on the third recount by a margin of only two votes. Since then the Tory party has moreorless folded in Scotland).  Beyond that the evidence suggests that loyalty to Brexit stance is greater than loyalty to Party so there is less reason why voters should stick with parties they voted for last time.

I see three likely holds.
More thought later
